Why do we depend on macros like PLATFORM_WINDOWS and COMPILER_MSVC other than _WIN32 and _MSC_VER ? _WIN32 and _MSC_VER are builtin macros, we don't need to pass them through compiler command line args.

Now we have such code in some header files:

#if defined(PLATFORM_WINDOWS) 
x = 1;
#else
x = 2;
#endif

Then, we have to add "-DPLATFORM_WINDOWS" to the copts of every file who includes such header. Otherwise, we'll get incorrect behavior at runtime.

body:
Why do we depend on macros like PLATFORM\_WINDOWS and COMPILER\_MSVC other than \_WIN32 and \_MSC\_VER ? \_WIN32 and \_MSC\_VER are builtin macros, we don't need to pass them through compiler command line args. 

Now we have such code in some header files:
```c
#if defined(PLATFORM_WINDOWS) 
x = 1;
#else
x = 2;
#endif
```
Then, we have to add "-DPLATFORM\_WINDOWS" to the copts of every file who includes such header.  Otherwise, we'll get incorrect behavior at runtime.
